texts.shortText:
Cyamids are very unusual parasitic amphipods with strongly flattened, usually oval bodies. The first pair of legs (gnathopod 1) bears large, powerful nippers and the second pair much smaller ones. The third and fourth pairs of legs are entirely missing and only gills are present on those body segments. Legs 5-7 are powerful, extended laterally and end in large grasping claws for clinging to the skin of their cetacean hosts.

Several species occur in the region, each distinguished largely by the form of the gills, as well as by association with particular hosts. In this species the gills each consist of two elongate ‘sausages’ with a pair of shorter crescent-shaped accessory gills at their bases. This is one of three whale louse species associated with Southern right whales.

Global: Widespread across North and South Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean and Southern Ocean.

Local/Regional: Whole region.

One of several local cyamid amphipods that have parasitic relationships with different cetaceans, most species being associated with only one, or a small group of closely-related hosts.

 Whale lice tend to favour areas where they obtain some shelter from water currents, for example around the blow-holes, genital or other body opening, in wounds and especially around the callosities of right whales. Also in areas previously infested with whale barnacles (Coronula diadema). The entire life-cycle occurs on the host, with juveniles simply moving from the brood pouch of adult females directly onto the adjacent skin. Transfer between individual hosts presumably only occurs when hosts touch one another.

Genetic relationships between parasites collected from different whale populations can be used to infer how connected these populations are and suggest that Northern and Southern hemisphere populations have exchanged parasites within the past 1-2 million years.
Cyamids are thought feed on algae that settle on the body of the host, but also ingest skin flakes and tissue around wounds. They are not though to cause significant damage to their hosts.
Females bear paired ventral brood plates that form a marsupial chamber within which the eggs develop into fully formed juveniles.

This group is very easily recognised by their compact, flattened bodies, absence of third and fourth pair of legs and grasping posterior limbs, as well of course by their unique associations with cetaceans.

Three species of whale lice are found associated with Southern right whales, but of these this is the only species with two equal primary gill lobes. The other species have only one primary gill lobe (plus small crescentic lobes at base of each). They are C. gracilis, which has a narrow, almost parallel-sided body and short gills (each as long as only 2 body segments) and C. erraticus, which has much longer gills (as long as 4 body segments).
